newsitem.title: MALAYSIA: Malaysia won't borrow for development projects.
newsitem.headline: Malaysia won't borrow for development projects.

text.p: Malaysia will not incur any more debts to carry out development projects and will adopt a pragmatic approach by ensuring that only vital projects are implemented first, Deputy Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim said on Sunday.

Many countries had offered to provide loans to Malaysia but the government would not take up the offer because new debt would be a burden to the future generation, he was quoted as saying by the national Bernama news agency.
As such, he said, all matters related to development, especially in the rural areas, would be dealt with in stages.
Anwar, who is also finance minister, said that just like household expenditure, the government would implement projects according to its financial means.
He added that in the management of the economy, not everything would work out as planned.
"Therefore, when we are criticised over any shortcomings, we will accept them...but they should not merely be to run us down," he said.
Malaysia expects its outstanding external debts to decline to 10.675 billion ringgit at the end of this year from 13.33 billion at end-1995.
